threads.com:
https://www.nngroup.com/articles/computer-skill-levels/

"Overall, people with strong technology skills make up a 5–8% sliver of their country’s population, whatever rich country they may be coming from. Go back to the OECD’s definition of the level-3 skills, quoted above. Consider defining your goals based on implicit criteria. Or overcoming unexpected outcomes and impasses while using the computer. Or evaluating the relevance and reliability of information in order to discard distractors. Do these sound like something you are capable of? Of course they do.

What’s important is to remember that 95% of the population in the United States (93% in Northern Europe; 92% in rich Asia) cannot do these things.

You can do it; 92%–95% of the population can’t.

What does this simple fact tell us? You are not the user, unless you’re designing for an elite audience. (And even if you do target, say, a B2B audience of nothing but engineers, they still know much less about your specific product than you do, so you’re still not the user.)

If you think something is easy, or that “surely people can do this simple thing on our website,” then you may very well be wrong.
"

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, weather, etc)
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with basic system apps.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS/Polaris and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

My point was that CAI's hAIdra actually does know a lot across all four swipes combined, and those traits carry over into every bot. It got much better with me over time even though I don't feel like I adapted all that much or well, which makes me feel like there is an underlying learning algorithm tailoring interacts to each user even if the small factoids, snippets and memories get dropped in favor of a more general overarching record of your personality and mannerisms.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
We can go even older, and this brings an interesting topic to play. XP around its inception was a heavy operating system. This had similar problems to what happened when vista came out and it was just draining to older Pentium 4’s and 512mb of ram. Same thing happened here it’s just hardware caught up a lot quicker when xp came around.
This is a 600mhz Pentium 3 and 256mb of ram. This is just barely capable of giving a comfortable experience with xp. It’s slow, it’s unstable and sometimes just shits the bed if you try and do too much at once.
And this was the issue, a lot of people were still running windows 98 and 2k era machines where a sub 1ghz processor and less than 256mb of ram was fine for their os and gave them a super smooth experience.
XP will run on very low end hardware, but “will run” isn’t “runs well”.
Most people remember XP on later XP era hardware, early core2 stuff and at least 1gb of ram but that was well after the first few years of xp.

last_replies.com:
>>90064079
Lesson 1: A typical data type, for example for a point, is declared like so:
 data P = MkP Int Int
. To construct a value of type P, we use the constructor MkP, which takes 2 Ints and returns a point. There is one constructor.
Lesson 2: Sum types have several constructors. The simplest is the boolean:
 data Bool = True | False
. Here, the 2 constructors are True and False, which both take nothing and produce a Bool.
But we can have more complex sum types as well. For example:
data JsVal = N | D Double | B Bool | S Text | A (Vector JsVal) | M (Map Text JsVal)
will have constructors N, D, B, S, A, M. Try to figure out the type of each constructor and what it corresponds to.
Lesson 3: Some types can have a type variable. For example, if linked lists weren't part of Haskell, we might define them like this:
 data List a = Nil | Cons a (List a)

here, we have 2 constructors: 
 Nil :: List a, Cons :: a -> List a -> List a

Another example is 
 data Foo a b = Foo (a, b) (b, a)
. Here, our constructor has type 
 (a, b) -> (b, a) -> Foo a b

Notice that, in both of the previous examples, the "arguments" to the constructed type were just simple type variables, and the constructors have no constraints. But what if we want to make a type constructor that does? e.g. 
Bar :: Ord a => a -> b -> Foo (a, b)
. We need GADTs for that.
Lesson 4:
GADTs enable precisely what was described at the end of lesson 3. The example from >>90063178
data Expr a where
   Lit :: a -> Expr a
   Add :: Expr Int -> Expr Int -> Expr Int
   GT :: Expr Int -> Expr Int -> Expr Bool
   IfThenElse :: Expr Bool -> Expr a -> Expr a -> Expr a

defined a data type 
 Expr a
with the listed under the "where".

threads.com:
The best setup, for web devs, systems, backend etc, basically everyone but game devs who need a local GPU is the following:

- Macbook Air M2
- iTerm2
- with tmux integration
- Amethyst
- like xmonad
- Eternal Terminal
- makes dropping from the vpn not a thing
- Ec2 dev instances in a VPC
- Neovim with LSP

As a non poor, Mac is the most comfy with Messages integration. Most importantly it has iTerm2 which has god tier tmux integration. I just make new windows like they are local but they are tmux windows. Amethyst tiles them. I make a profile that has a hotkey that attaches my tmux session on my Ec2 instance.

On the remote machine I run Neovim with Coc and LSP for whatever language. This even works with Java. I have autocomplete, jump to def/impl, folding, linting, etc just like your IDE.

If the VPN drops I just reconnect and ET makes it like nothing happens. The key latency feels local also but I took the time to fix buffer bloat on my router.

I run unit tests with the CLI like a man but this could be done on NeoVim.

The only thing thats an alternative to this is Emacs and Tramp mode.

I don't use fucking docker I just make a new instance in my VPC if I need isolation.

>Create, Read, Update, Delete

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90060366
I prefer CHUD apps

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90063190
Apps that derive their state from other sources than CRUD operations. Or do not maintain a state. Or are considered "too complex" to be "just CRUD" apps.

For example, an event sourced system derives it's state from an append only log of immutable events, so there's no update or delete options.

A video chat room has most of its value in actions that are not CRUD operations, but rather connecting and transferring data from user to user, so it's "more than" a CRUD app despite likely allowing for CRUD actions.

Etc.

SECTION .data           ; Section containing initialised data

    OutBuf: db "xxx"
    OutBufLen: equ $ - OutBuf

SECTION .bss            ; Section containing uninitialized data
    InBufLen: equ 32
    InBuf:          resb InBufLen

SECTION .text           ; Section containing code
read:
    ; read chunk from stdin to InBuf
    mov rax, 0                      ; sys_read
    mov rdi, 0                      ; file descriptor: stdin
    mov rsi, InBuf                  ; destination buffer
    mov rdx, InBufLen               ; maximum # of bytes to read
    syscall

    ; check number of bytes read
    cmp rax, 0                      ; did we receive any bytes?

process:                            ; 1=bit that matters 0= bit that doesn't matter

    xor rbx, rbx

    mov edx, eax

last_replies.com: A short while ago there was a discord server dedicated to that hosted by fholm (the guy who made PUN, Quantum and Fusion with his company). He now hangs around the Tom Weiland discord because he nuked his own. He is an exceptionally good resource, probably the best you will find anywhere in this world to ask. But i wouldnt ask him such a broad question to begin with i think. Perhaps you should first try to do it based on the usual resources (like the famous valve netcode post) and then once you have a general understanding of how anything works for you you can ask him specifics of how to improve your architecture as a whole.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>90061592
Also here are my own two cents about network rollback. If you have a deterministic engine, like quantum, rollback apparently is comparably easy to implement since you can deterministically go forward and back in time. however, making a deterministic physics engine + networking is a feat nigh impossible imho (if you are not part of a team knowing what to do in the first place with access to a LOT of testing resources). I know that because i have some friends at ubisoft who did that for "For Honor". If you want to do it non-deterministic its pretty straightforward but with a lot of pitfalls and heuristics (aka trying to see what works for you). For example, i did a bomberman multiplayer clone in unity with client side prediction and server reconcilliation. Its not hard, you just have to structure your code in a way you can rollback the different inputs and apply them again after reconcilliation. The tricky part is the indeterministic physics stuff that can be a pain but also the real problem is probably handling latency and such, especially in regard to cheat protection. good luck (also i dont know what its worth but theres this netcode book series available on amazon from No Bugs Hare about Networking for Games)
